Situation1: They share their work challenges and personal concerns after noticing their spouse seems worried.
Situation2: They develop a floor plan for a new office, ensuring workspaces accommodate employees’ needs efficiently.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, blueprints spread out before me, my pencil tapping a nervous rhythm. The office project deadline loomed, and I was still struggling to make the break room accessible without sacrificing desk space. My mind raced with measurements and layouts, but I couldn’t ignore the way my husband lingered by the sink, quieter than usual. I knew I should ask him what was wrong, open up the conversation like we always promised we would. But every time I looked at him, my thoughts snapped back to the floor plan—if I didn’t solve this, the whole design would fall apart. I felt torn, the weight of my professional responsibility pressing against the promise I’d made to be present and supportive at home. My heart ached with guilt as I tried to focus on both, but the demands pulled me in opposite directions, leaving me paralyzed between the person I wanted to be for him and the architect I needed to be for my team.
